history.content:
I took both and thought they were easily the two most interesting classes in my EECS education so you've made the right choices. I think EE 120 and EE 130 represent the two sides of the EE coin much much better than 16A and B do so you're not missing much.

EE 120: This is mostly a mathematical methods class. Useful for general engineering because it turns out a lot of physical systems can be modeled using linearity and time-shifting. The most important prereqs for this would be Math 1B, Math 54, and Physics 7B. Math 1B because the class deals a lot with improper integration and some odd integral techniques, Math 54 because a study of linear systems uses concepts from linear algebra like orthogonality and inner products, and 7B because the examples that the classes use are often rooted in E&M due to it being an EE class. You don't want your first time hearing about an RLC circuit transient response to be this class, but 7A and B should be enough of a physics primer.

EE 130: This class is an applied physics class. You definitely need Physics 7B for this class, since the class deals with how electrons flow through solid-state devices. The class is mostly a primer on solid-state physics followed by derivations of current models through different electron device geometries. No math necessary beyond that needed for 7B. However, you might be missing some context without EE 105. You'll be able to work out the current characteristics of a biased MOSFET, but if you don't really know what a MOSFET is used for, it'll seem pointless and arbitrary. The models you derive in this class are the ones used in EE 105, but in EE 105 you actually discuss how to build amplifiers. EE 130 will make you really prepared for EE 105, but EE 105 is definitely doable without EE 130.

As a note, if you're not planning on taking 16AB, 120 might be necessary before 105 (but not for 130). The reason is that 105 starts off by introducing how closed-loop circuits affect amplifier gain. Simple amplifier circuits are discussed in 16 and will not be reviewed in 105, but the abstract treatment of feedback loops covered in EE 120 coupled with a physics intuition should be more than enough to make up for it.

children.subject:
I think it depends on what you're studying. 105 is an application of 130, but far from the only application of it. You'll definitely find it useful for fields like photovoltaic cells or microfabrication. I think the lack of "motivation" in 130 isn't a problem if you know what you're going to use the class for.

I took it specifically to get better at analog circuit design since that's the most obvious application of device physics. If you're planning to go into any kind of engineering or physics where you need to understand how electronic devices are modeled, it'll be pretty insightful.

You can take 130 without 105.  The device physics courses are more specifically geared towards digital/logic use, so 105 does not really apply.  And often in 130 you have to "unlearn" the little devices material taught in 105 anyways (105 does not go over band theory, the basis for all device physics).  So go for it!

That's interesting. When I took the two classes simultaneously, it worked out really well because the equations I was using in 105 were exactly those derived in 130. I remember 130 being really helpful for the part of 105 where they explain the behavior of a PN junction, as well as explaining where MOSFET linear and saturation regions really come from.

I'm not a digital person though, so my view is definitely biased. I don't doubt that 130 is useful for digital design as well.

OP here, just wanted to thank you guys for the input! It was really insightful and I think I'll do EE 130 with 120 after reading the responses.

If you guys have any info about the workload or difficulty, that'd be great to know too. Otherwise, thanks for the suggestions!

Hey thanks a lot! That was very helpful and detailed. I definitely want to take 120 now. 

I'm a bit worried about the missing context part for EE 130 though. I'm not sure I can take 105 afterwards. Would it still be worth it to take 130 without possibly going into EE 105?

history.content:
Non-EECS major here but wanted to take those classes out of interest. The prereqs for both are EE 16A+B, but I've heard you can do fine in them if you did fine in Physics 7B and Math 54. 

Anyone who took the classes can comment? Would it be a bad idea to take either without EE16A and B?
history.subject: EE 130 and EE 120 Prereqs
